Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: I stared at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing insistently. As a colleague, I was expected to join our weekly team catch-up, share updates, and show I was engaged. Even though it was routine and would be recorded, I knew my absence would be noticed—my manager always appreciated visible participation. But as I glanced at the insulated box in my van, my other role pressed in. The label was clear: urgent medical supplies, hospital delivery, time-stamped for the next hour. If I delayed, patient care could be compromised. My supervisor at the delivery company had drilled it into us—timeliness was non-negotiable, especially for medical runs. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between being a reliable teammate and a responsible delivery person. My mind raced, weighing the disappointment of my colleagues against the potential consequences for patients. The clock ticked on, and I sat frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice between two worlds that both demanded my presence.
